qas.question: Which group or religion dominates the Aslatian population?
Which other large religion also exist in Alsace due to the once German presence?
What is the name of the Union created by France's second largest Protestant church?
What is the name of the second largest Roman Catholic church?
When was the Calvinist EPRAL formed?
What religious faith does not get public subsidies?
When did Alsace split from Imperial Germany?

plausible_answers.text: law separating the French church and state

context: Most of the Alsatian population is <a0_0>Roman Catholic<a0_0/>, but, largely because of the region's German heritage, a significant <a1_0>Protestant<a1_0/> community also exists: today, the <b3_0>EPCAAL<b3_0/> (a Lutheran church) is France's second largest Protestant church, also forming an administrative union (<a2_0>UEPAL<a2_0/>) with the much smaller Calvinist EPRAL. Unlike the rest of France, the Local law in Alsace-Moselle still provides for to the Napoleonic Concordat of <b4_0>1801<b4_0/> and the organic articles, which provides public subsidies to the Roman Catholic, Lutheran, and Calvinist churches, as well as to <b5_0>Jewish synagogues<b5_0/>; religion classes in one of these faiths is compulsory in public schools. This divergence in policy from the French majority is due to the region having been part of Imperial Germany when the <b6_0>1905<b6_0/> <b7_0>law separating the French church and state<b7_0/> was instituted (for a more comprehensive history, see: Alsace-Lorraine). Controversy erupts periodically on the appropriateness of this legal disposition, as well as on the exclusion of other religions from this arrangement.
